article_title: Bombardier Profit Falls on Lower Business-Jet Demand
article_text: SHARE THIS ARTICLE   Share   Tweet   Post   Email  {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"brokerboxarticle","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[120,60]],"small_desktop":[[120,60]],"tablet":[[120,60]]},"strategy":"viewable","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"brokerboxarticle1","url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"brokerboxarticle-3UsrBEN"}   Bombardier Inc., the world’s third-largest commercial planemaker, said fiscal fourth-quarter profit declined 43 percent as the global recession curbed demand for business jets.    Net income dropped to $177 million, or 10 cents a share, from $309 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier, the Montreal- based company said in a statement today. Analysts, on average, estimated profit of 11 cents a share. Sales fell 1.4 percent to $5.35 billion in the period ended Jan. 31.    {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[1,8]],"small_desktop":[[1,8]],"tablet":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"outstream-video-1-L06ZUN6VJ6RK01"}   {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"mobile":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"outstream-video-2-L06ZUN6VJ6RK01"}   Bombardier announced more than 5,000 job cuts in its aerospace division last year as Chief Executive Officer Pierre Beaudoin adjusted production to match sliding demand. The transportation unit’s revenue increased on sales of commuter trains to Europe and high-speed trains to China.    {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"box","dimensions":{"mobile":[[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"]},"type":"Mobile Body Box Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"box1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"box-6hGAyLD"}   “Bombardier’s aerospace business will take another year before demand, revenues and margins start to recover,” Richard Stoneman, an analyst with Dundee Capital Markets, wrote in a note before the results were released. “On the other hand, the transportation group has demonstrated strong order flow, revenues growth and improved margins over the past year.”    Bombardier fell 52 cents, or 8.3 percent, to C$5.71 at 4:15 p.m. in Toronto Stock Exchange trading. The shares have still climbed 88 percent in the past 12 months.  {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"desktop-in-article1","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[5,4]],"small_desktop":[[5,4]]},"type":"Desktop in article Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"desktop-in-article1","url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"desktop-in-article-1-L06ZUN6VJ6RK01"}   Bombardier today repeated a Feb. 5 announcement that it expects to deliver about 15 percent fewer business aircraft and 20 percent fewer commercial aircraft in 2011 than in the past fiscal year. The backlog for the CSeries, a family of airliners under development, is now 90, the company said.  Backlog, Orders  “We’ve basically progressed through our backlog here and orders are important right now for this coming year,” Guy Hachey, president of the company’s aerospace division, said during a conference call today.  {"contentId":"L06ZUN6VJ6RK01","position":"in-article1","dimensions":{"mobile":[[5,19],[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"],"tablet":[[5,11],[728,90],[1,1]]},"type":"In Article Flex Native Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"in-article1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2010-04-01/bombardier-profit-falls-43-percent-on-lower-demand-for-business-aircraft"},"containerId":"in-article-1-L06ZUN6VJ6RK01"}   Bombardier received 33 net aerospace orders in the quarter, compared with six a year earlier. Also in the just-ended quarter, the company delivered 86 aircraft, consisting of 49 business planes, 35 commercial aircraft and two amphibious vehicles. A year earlier, the company delivered 54 business planes, 37 commercial aircraft and two amphibious vehicles.  The companywide backlog was $43.8 billion at the end of the quarter, down from $48.2 billion a year earlier. Since the period ended, Bombardier has announced orders valued at 1.15 billion euros ($1.56 billion) from SNCF, France’s national rail service, and a $3.06 billion order for CSeries aircraft from Republic Airways Holdings Inc.  Trains, Jets  SNCF ordered 80 double-deck regional trains in February, and exercised an option for 49 more in March. Republic Airways agreed to buy 40 CS300 regional jets in February.  Airbus SAS is the world’s largest maker of commercial aircraft, followed by Boeing Co.  Bombardier delivered 302 aircraft in fiscal 2010, compared with 349 in 2009. The 2010 deliveries consisted of 176 business planes, 121 commercial aircraft and five amphibious craft. In fiscal 2009, Bombardier delivered 235 business planes, 110 commercial aircraft and four amphibious vehicles.  (Adds closing share price in fifth paragraph.)
